feed.title: Category: picks | User group for Viennese rubyists

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
26/02 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the forty-fourth edition:

Laura:
  • WhatTheCommit – Inspiration for your commit messages
  • Kod.io Linz – Guess what’s on this weekend? Come join us in Linz!
  • Power Rake – Jim Weirich’s GoRuCo 2012 talk about the “hidden” features of rake
Alex:
  • hipster dev deck – A curated directory of artisanal development tools that we used to like before they went mainstream
  • First Time User Experiences – A showcase of new user experiences, good and bad, from a variety of products.
  • Authorization – Handling Authorization in a Service-Oriented Architecture
Ben:
  • Eye – Process monitoring tool. Inspired from Bluepill and God.
  • Atom – A new Editor by the GitHub guys.
  • Base – One Base Class to Rule Them All

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
19/02 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the forty-third edition:

Laura:
  • Boxen – Automate the pain out of your development environment
  • Acts As Enid – Following my own link from last week, I put together a useless gem that spits out quotes from Ghost World. Enidify!
Alex:
  • RubyMotion – Building OS X apps with RubyMotion
  • North – Design and development standards to align and guide your project.
  • UX Fundamentals – UX crash course – 31 fundamentals
Ben:
  • iPhone – How Apple Protects Your iPhone from Your Employer
  • The Passion Gospel – it’s a long piece, make sure to read the whole piece
  • fleet – Cluster-Level Container Deployment with fleet

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
12/02 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the forty-second edition:

Laura:
  • GitSh – An interactive shell for Git
  • Acts as Charlie Sheen – Make your own Charlie Sheen gem
  • 100 days later – “To form a habit, commit to do it often”
Alex:
  • Clever Algorithms – Nature-Inspired Programming Recipes
  • Brackets – Brackets is an open source code editor for web designers and front-end developers.
  • Docker on Mac – How To Install Docker On Mac OS X

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
05/02 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the forty-first edition:

Laura:
  • Open Data – Thirty places to find open data on the web
  • Figaro – A clean and simple way to configure your (open source) app and keep the private stuff private
  • Raptor Editor – Haven’t tried it yet, but the name is just too cool
Alex:
  • The Magic Tricks of Testing – Sandi Metz about testing
  • Regularity – A friendly regular expression builder for Ruby
  • AngularJS and Rails 4 – How to integrate AngularJS with Rails 4
Ben:
  • The Magic of Strace – know your tools! how to get some insights into your UNIX processes
  • Making Time for Side Projects – Planning is key!
  • Don’t let your shell manage your ENV vars – Use tools like Dotenv or Figaro instead!
Tony:
  • Switcher – The website switching extension you always wanted. A Chrome Extension for devs.
  • Who Dictates Software Quality: Client or Coder? – And how about you?
  • ominref – comprehensive ruby documentation search

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
29/01 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks – or: what we think is worth sharing – every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the fortieth edition:

Laura:
  • Austria Game Jam 2014 – The links to this year’s games are online. Play away!
  • Web applications with Ruby (not Rails) – David Padilla’s talk from ArrrrCamp.
  • Have I been pwned? – …because data breaches.
Alex:
  • 467 tests, 0 failures, 0 confidence – Katrina Owen about the purpose of tests.
  • Trailer – A faster and easier way to deal with pull requests
  • Dot Navigation Styles – Subtle effects for simple dot navigation
Ben:
  • Tales of an Ops Team: Confessions of a Chatbot
  • Prototype based programming – Featuring: Self, NewtonScript, Io, and, yes, JavaScript. Plus: the dunder is back
Tony:
  • $://showterm – Record Terminal Sessions! And it’s in Ruby, too!
  • Of Orcs and Software Craftsmanship – XML parsing, a developer’s view. Don’t let the foreign language (=Java) discourage you!
  • International Table Top Day – Play More Games! (I admit, I am a fan)
